intro: Boehmeria fallax var. ulmifolia, commonly known as the silky dogwood, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia. It belongs to the Urticaceae family and is characterized by its soft, silken fibers in its stems, which are often used in textile production. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and stream banks. Its leaves are alternate, heart-shaped, and have a distinctive silvery-white underside. It produces small greenish-white flowers clustered in umbels, which are pollinated by insects.
